fr:mainmatter.fr:p: nLab is a wiki for collaborative work on Mathematics, Physics, and Philosophy — especially (but far from exclusively) from the higher structures point of view: with a sympathy towards the tools and perspectives of homotopy theory/algebraic topology, homotopy type theory, higher category theory and higher categorical algebra.

This post discuss the universe in type theory, based on Egbert Rijke's Introduction to Homotopy Type Theory and NLab. In this post, we regard universe as the representation of types in an internal model of the type theory (Tarski universe or universe à la Tarski).

A universe consist of a type \mathcal {U} with a type family \mathcal {T} over \mathcal {U}. Forall X:\mathcal {U} we think of X as an encoding (representation) of the actual type \mathcal {T}(X). The type family \mathcal {T} is therefore called a unversal type family.

There several reasons to equip type theory with universes. It enables us to define new type families over inductive types, using induction principle. For instance, we can define relations over \mathbb {N}, such as ordering relations \leq . We will soon meet the idea of observational equality for a particular type, different from identity types. Another reason is that it allows us to define types equipped with structure such as group.

A universe consists of a type \mathcal {U} of which the elements are representations of types. It is equipped with a type family \mathcal {T} indexed by \mathcal {U} called universal type family. The universe is closed under all the type constructors in the sense that it comes equipped with the following structure:
\mathcal {U} is closed under \Pi , equipped with a function \check {\Pi }:\Pi _{(X:\mathcal {U})}(\mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {U})\to \mathcal {U} for which the judgemental equality \mathcal {T}(\check {\Pi }(X,P))\equiv \Pi _{(x:\mathcal {T}(X))}\mathcal {T}(P(x)) holds forall X:\mathcal {U} and P:\mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {U}.
\mathcal {U} is closed under \Sigma , equipped with a function \check {\Sigma }:\Pi _{(X:\mathcal {U})}(\mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {U})\to \mathcal {U} for which the judgemental equality \mathcal {T}(\check {\Sigma }(X,P))\equiv \Sigma _{(x:\mathcal {T}(X))}\mathcal {T}(P(x)) holds forall X:\mathcal {U} and P:\mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {U}.
\mathcal {U} is closed under identity types, equipped with a function \check {I}:\Pi _{(X:\mathcal {U})}\mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {U} for which the judgemental equality \mathcal {T}(\check {I}(X,x,y))\equiv (x=y) holds forall X:\mathcal {U} and x,y:\mathcal {T}(X).
\mathcal {U} is closed under coproducts, equipped with a function \check {+}:\Pi _{(X:\mathcal {U})}(\mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {U})\to \mathcal {U} that satisfies the judgemental equality \mathcal {T}(X\check {+}P)\equiv \mathcal {T}(X)+\mathcal {T}(P)
\mathcal {U} contains elements \check {\textbf {1}}, \check {\textbf {0}}, \check {\mathbb {N}} : \mathcal {U} that satisfies the judgemental equality \mathcal {T}(\check {\textbf {0}})\equiv \textbf {0}, \\ \mathcal {T}(\check {\textbf {1}})\equiv \textbf {1}, \\ \mathcal {T}(\check {\mathbb {N}})\equiv \mathbb {N} Consider a universe \mathcal {U} and a type A in context \Gamma . We say that A is a type in \mathcal {U} or that \mathcal {U} contains A, if there is an element \check {A}:\mathcal {U} such that \Gamma \vdash \mathcal {T}(\check {A})\equiv A\space \space \text {type} holds.

Sometimes we may consider the universe \mathcal {U} itself to be a type in some universes. If we have only one \mathcal {U}, the Russell Paradox may arise. Therefore we assume that there are enough universes
Using the assumption we can obtain many specific universes.
The base universee \mathcal {U}_0 is defined using universe postulate with empty context.
Using successor universes we can create an infinite tower of universes.

Now we give the example of observational equality of \mathbb {N}. The key idea is to define a recursive function that reduce the arguments. Observational equality an inductively defined relation, which gives us an algorithm for checking equality on \mathbb {N}. It can be used to show that equality of natural numbers is decidable.

The observational equality of \mathbb {N} is a binary relation \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}:\mathbb {N}\to (\mathbb {N}\to \mathcal {U}_0) satisfies \begin {align*} \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(0)(0) &\equiv \textbf {1} \\ \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(0)(\text {succ}(n)) &\equiv \textbf {0} \\ \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(\text {succ}(m))(0) &\equiv \textbf {0} \\ \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(\text {succ}(m))(\text {succ}(n)) &\equiv \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(m)(n) \end {align*}
674#306unstable-306.xmlProofdef-004H We define \text {Eq} by double induction on \mathbb {N}. By the first application of induction it suffices to provide \begin {align*} &E_0:\mathbb {N}\to \mathcal {U}_0 \\ &E_S:\mathbb {N}\to ((\mathbb {N}\to \mathcal {U}_0)\to (\mathbb {N}\to \mathcal {U}_0)) \end {align*} we define E_0 by induction: \begin {align*} &E_0(0) \equiv \textbf {1}\\ &E_0(\text {succ}(n)) \equiv \textbf {0} \end {align*} and also define E_S by induction: \begin {align*} &E_S(n,X,0)\equiv \textbf {0}\\ &E_S(n,X,\text {succ}(m))\equiv X(m) \end {align*} Therefore we have by the computation rule for the first induction that the following judgemental equality holds. \begin {align*} \text {Eq}(0,m) &\equiv E_0(m) \\ \text {Eq}(\text {succ}(n),m) &\equiv E_S(n,\text {Eq}(n),m) \end {align*}

Observational equality of \mathbb {N} is a reflexive relation, i.e. we have \text {refl-Eq}_\mathbb {N}:\Pi _{(n:\mathbb {N})}\text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(n,n) which is witnessed by induction on n. \begin {align*} \text {refl-Eq}_\mathbb {N}(0) &\equiv \star \\ \text {refl-Eq}_\mathbb {N}(\text {succ}(n)) &\equiv \text {refl-Eq}_\mathbb {N}(n) \end {align*}
This leads to an interesting dual perspective on equality. For any two natural numbers m and n we have (m=n)\leftrightarrow \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(m,n)

Using the observational equality of \mathbb {N} we can prove Peano's seventh and eighth axioms.
For any two natural numbers m and n we have (m = n)\leftrightarrow (\text {succ}(m) = \text {succ}(n))
For any natural number n we have 0 \not = \text {succ}(n)
This is a collection of notes on categorical semantics for type theories. The notes are based on the paper by Jason Z.S. Hu and NLab.

Over the last few decades, many type systems are designed for different purposes: general program safety, security, and correctness. The categorical semantics is a collection of methods which define meanings of types and programs in category theory.

Category theory is a branch of mathematics studying an abstract kind of mappings, called morphisms, and their algebraic relations. Its generality serves as a common language for navigating connections between different concepts in different areas. We will first go over some basic concepts in category theory.
Formally, a definition in category theory consists of two parts: data and axioms. The most basic definition is the category

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
A category C consists
A collection of objects C_0 (\text {Ob}(C)).
A collection C_1 (\text {Mor}(C)) of morphisms (arrows).
For every morphism f there are an object s(f) (source, domain) and an object t(f) (target, codomain).
For every pair of morphisms f, g such that t(f) = s(g), there is a morphism g \circ f (composition) (Also written gf or f;g).
For every object x, there is a morphism \text {id}_x (or 1_x) called identity.
The following properties hold:
s(g \circ f) = s(f) and t(g \circ f) = t(g).
s(1_x) = x and t(1_x) = x.
Composition is associative: h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ f when t(f) = s(g), and t(g) = s(h).
Composition satifies the identity laws: f \circ \text {id}_x = f and \text {id}_y \circ f = f If the identity map and its axioms are omitted then one speaks of a semicategory.

fr:title.text: With a family of collections of morphisms
fr:title.fr:strong: With a family of collections of morphisms

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
A category C consists
A collection of objects C_0 (\text {Ob}(C)).
For every pair of objects x, y, a collection C_1(x, y) (\hom _C(x,y)) of morphisms from x to y.
For each pair of morphisms f in C_1(x,y) and g in C_1(y,z), a morphism g \circ f in C_1(x,z). called their composition.
For each object x, a morphism \text {id}_x in C_1(x,x) called the identity on x.
The following properties hold:
Composition is associative: h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ f for all f in C_1(x,y), g in C_1(y,z), and h in C_1(z,w).
Composition satifies the identity laws: f \circ \text {id}_x = f and \text {id}_y \circ f = f for all f in C_1(x,y). Usually we write \text {Mor}(C) for the disjoint union \bigsqcup _{x,y \in C_0} C_1(x,y).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We only talk about collections here, which is vague, because we do not specify they are sets or classes. If both objects and morphisms fit in sets, we say the category is small. For a counterexample, the category of all sets is not small. However, all functions between sets can be contained in a set. In this case, the category is locally small. When morphisms between two objects fit in a set, we call the set hom-set.

Since category theory is constructed to study structures and a category is actually a structure, we can talk about the category of all small categories \mathbf {Cat}. Similar to morphisms, we can define functor between categories.

A functor F from a category C to a category D is a map sending each x\in C to an object F(x)\in D and each morphism f:x\to y in C to morphism F(f):F(x)\to F(y) in D, such that
Composition is preserved: F(g\circ f) = F(g)\circ F(f).
Identity is preserved: F(\text {id}_x) = \text {id}_{F(x)}.
We can push this idea further by considering functors as objects and natural transformations as morphisms.

Let C and D be categories, the functor category D^C (or [C,D]) is the category whose
objects are functors from C to D.
morphisms are natural transformations between functors.

Here we use a commutative diagram to represent a natural transformation. When a diagram commutes, morphisms composed by different paths with the same end points are equal. The following diagram represents the equality that G(f)\circ \alpha _x = \alpha _y\circ F(f).

Though the theory is already rich by only considering sets and categories, it would not be interesting enough. We want to know a little more about the category that we are working with. To achieve so, we can require some additional structures on the category. A common structure is the cartesian product.
With this definition, it is natural to ask what can serve as a nullary product. The concept is characterized by terminal objects.

When making math statements, we often encounter concepts that are dual to each other. In category theory, this phenomenon is captured by the concept of duality. Intuitively, duality offers us free dual theorem from the original one.
For a category \mathcal {C}, the opposite category \mathcal {C}^{op} has the same objects as \mathcal {C}, but the morphisms are reversed.
For example, the product in the opposite category, all universal properties corresponds to a dual concept.

One important principle in type theory is the Curry-Howard Isomorphism (Propositions as types). It depicts the connection between logic and types. A program can represent a logical argument, and operations in logic find meaningful correspondences in program execution. The principle was later extended with category theory due to Lambek. In his work, he showed a correspondence between STLC and Cartesian Closed Categories (CCC) and revealed the connection between types and categories. The correspondence is called the Curry-Howard-Lambek Isomorphism.

In general, there are two approaches to understand or design a type system: the syntactic view and semantic view.
The syntactic view focuses on the syntactic structure of types and programs. We study about subject reduction, cut elimination and etc, simply by manipulating the syntax. It is usually more direct and easier to understand as it is often conducted via induction on some syntactic structures. And it also suggest algorithms which can be implemented. The disadvantage is that it is limited and hard to proof some properties like normalization.
The semantic appoaches are more powerful in general. It is based on mathematics models of type systems. In exchange of the strength and generality, it is usually harder to understand and heavyweight, requries more intuition of the concepts.

One clasical semantic approach to logic is algebraic logic. A logical system is modeled by some algebraic theory. (often related to lattices and semi-lattices). Famous examples include Boolean algebras for classic propositional logic and Heyting algebras for intuitionistic counterpart. The algebraic logic is a powerful tool to study the properties of logical systems, but has a limitation that all operations are limited in one structured set.
An important result from ategorical semantics could be monads. In Moggi's paper, he showed that monads can be used to model computational effects.
It requires an operation over functors named whiskering

Let F,G:C\to D and H,D\to E be functors and \eta :F\to G be a natural transformation whose coordinate at any object A of C is \eta _A, then whiskering H and \eta yields the natural transformation H\circ \eta :H\circ F\to H\circ G whose coordinate at A is H(\eta _A).

Categorical logic is a new approach to logic, due to Lawvere. He showed that logical constructs are fundamentally just adjoint functors. This allows us to capture many logical constructs by using only one categorical concept. Adjoint also provides a strong guarantee about the derived syntactic formulation.

Let \mathcal {C} and \mathcal {D} be categories and a pair of functors F:\mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} and G:\mathcal {D}\to \mathcal {C}. This is called pair of adjoint functors (or adjunction) with F the left adjoint and G the right adjoint denoted F\dashv G if there is a natural isomorphism between the hom-functors: \hom _{\mathcal {D}}(F(-),-)\cong \hom _{\mathcal {C}}(-,G(-)) which means forall objects C\in \mathcal {C} and D\in \mathcal {D}, there is a bijection \hom _{\mathcal {D}}(F(C),D)\cong \hom _{\mathcal {C}}(C,G(D)) \\ (F(C)\xrightarrow {f}D) \mapsto (C\xrightarrow {G(f)}G(D)) which is natural in both C and D.
This note is about the category theory and its applications. Instead of reading a well-organized book, I prefer to write down the things I learned from ncatlab and papers.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Intuitively, a category is a collection of objects and arrows between them, such arrows can be composed and there is an identity arrow for each object.
There are commonly two ways to define a category, which are equivalent in usual foundations of mathematics. One of them generalizes the notion of internal category nicely while the other one is more convenient for enriched category.
The major difference is whether they use a single collection of all morphisms or several collections of morphisms (family of collections indexed by pairs of objects)

A category C consists
A collection of objects C_0 (\text {Ob}(C)).
A collection C_1 (\text {Mor}(C)) of morphisms (arrows).
For every morphism f there are an object s(f) (source, domain) and an object t(f) (target, codomain).
For every pair of morphisms f, g such that t(f) = s(g), there is a morphism g \circ f (composition) (Also written gf or f;g).
For every object x, there is a morphism \text {id}_x (or 1_x) called identity.
The following properties hold:
s(g \circ f) = s(f) and t(g \circ f) = t(g).
s(1_x) = x and t(1_x) = x.
Composition is associative: h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ f when t(f) = s(g), and t(g) = s(h).
Composition satifies the identity laws: f \circ \text {id}_x = f and \text {id}_y \circ f = f If the identity map and its axioms are omitted then one speaks of a semicategory.

fr:title.text: With a family of collections of morphisms
fr:title.fr:strong: With a family of collections of morphisms

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
A category C consists
A collection of objects C_0 (\text {Ob}(C)).
For every pair of objects x, y, a collection C_1(x, y) (\hom _C(x,y)) of morphisms from x to y.
For each pair of morphisms f in C_1(x,y) and g in C_1(y,z), a morphism g \circ f in C_1(x,z). called their composition.
For each object x, a morphism \text {id}_x in C_1(x,x) called the identity on x.
The following properties hold:
Composition is associative: h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ f for all f in C_1(x,y), g in C_1(y,z), and h in C_1(z,w).
Composition satifies the identity laws: f \circ \text {id}_x = f and \text {id}_y \circ f = f for all f in C_1(x,y). Usually we write \text {Mor}(C) for the disjoint union \bigsqcup _{x,y \in C_0} C_1(x,y).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Its common to talk about some objects and their morphisms. Informally, a diagram in a category C consists of some objects of C connected by some morphisms of C.
This terminology is often used when speaking about limits or colimits of a diagram.
One formal way to define a diagram is to use a functor from a (very) small category to C. That is, a functor whose domain is a small category.
A category is said to be small if it has a samll set (i.e. a set but not a proper class) of objects and morphisms. In other words a small category is an internal category in category of sets.

We did not explain what a functor is, but it is very natural thought. Briefly, a functor is a homomorphism between two categories. It maps objects to objects and morphisms to morphisms, preserving the structure of the categories.

A functor F from a category C to a category D is a map sending each x\in C to an object F(x)\in D and each morphism f:x\to y in C to morphism F(f):F(x)\to F(y) in D, such that
Composition is preserved: F(g\circ f) = F(g)\circ F(f).
Identity is preserved: F(\text {id}_x) = \text {id}_{F(x)}.
For the sake of completeness, we state the definition of the functor category and the natural transformations between functors.

Let C and D be categories, the functor category D^C (or [C,D]) is the category whose
objects are functors from C to D.
morphisms are natural transformations between functors.
We state the concise functorial definition of diagrams of the shape of categories.
Let C be a category and J be a small category. A diagram of shape J in C is a functor X:J\to C. The category of J-shaped diagrams in C is the functor category C^J.
A limit of a diagram F:D\to C is an object \lim F of C equipped with morphisms to the objects F(d) for all d\in D, such that everything in sight commutes.
